descriptions.description: High-quality software with more features enhances the project's public perception and credibility.
A larger user base provides more testimonials and visibility, which bolsters the project's reputation.
More core developers increases the total workload for reviews, potentially slowing down the process.
Longer review delays give developers more time to provide comprehensive and detailed feedback.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review generates a greater volume of feedback activity.
A rich base of implicit knowledge provides more material for experienced members to share via mentorship.
More core developers increases the capacity for one-on-one mentorship and implicit knowledge transfer.
Constructive feedback encourages newcomers, increasing their retention and transition into active contributors.
Positive and helpful feedback motivates experienced contributors to remain engaged and continue contributing.
Effective feedback helps contributors develop the skills and trust required to become core developers.
New contributors ask questions and seek clarifications, which generates more feedback interactions.
Experienced contributors provide answers and reviews, increasing the volume and quality of feedback.
Ongoing feedback cycles keep pull requests active and in the review queue longer.
Well-documented explicit knowledge makes it easier to create guides and onboard new contributors.
Feedback from code reviews and discussions becomes archived content for the knowledge base.
Resolved issues provide solutions and patterns that are added to the searchable knowledge base.
A comprehensive knowledge base serves as a primary source for the project's documented explicit knowledge.
Community discussions generate questions, answers, and decisions that enrich the knowledge base.
A strong project reputation attracts more users, expanding the overall user base.
More open issues generate more user reports, questions, and community feedback.
User feedback often reveals new problems or feature requests, leading to more open issues.
A healthy, collaborative community creates a positive public image that enhances project reputation.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, making it easier for new contributors to join.
A clear and fair governance strategy makes the project more attractive for potential contributors to join.
An effective governance strategy encourages participation, increasing the rate at which new contributors join.
A project's high reputation attracts more developers, increasing the contributor joining rate.
More maintainer time dedicated to issues accelerates the rate at which they are resolved.
Faster issue resolution directly increases the stock of closed issues.
A higher rate of new issue creation adds to the backlog of open issues.
Faster issue resolution reduces the number of open issues in the backlog.
More source code provides a larger surface area for bugs and feature requests, increasing issue creation.
Positive project activities and outcomes build up and accumulate the project's reputation over time.
Negative events or stagnation gradually erode and diminish the project's accumulated reputation.
As explicit knowledge is internalized and becomes tacit, it is no longer solely part of the explicit stock.
The process of creating new documentation and guides adds to the project's stock of explicit knowledge.
New users adopting the software increase the total user base.
Users leaving the project reduce the total user base.
Merging or committing a pull request removes it from the 'under review' stock.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the 'under review' stock.
Initiating a review on a new pull request adds it to the 'under review' stock.
Merging pull requests adds new code to the project's source code stock.
Access to good documentation helps contributors learn and advance their skills more quickly.
Effective mentorship accelerates learning and skill development for contributors.
Active community engagement produces discussions and solutions that are added to the knowledge base.
Open issues represent work to be done, which often inspires contributors to submit new pull requests.
New pull requests being submitted increase the stock of pull requests awaiting review.
Starting a review on a new pull request moves it from the 'new' queue to the 'under review' queue.
Developers leaving the project reduce the number of core developers.
Promoting experienced contributors to core roles increases the core developer count.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies experienced contributors for promotion to core roles.
When developers leave, they take their unique, unrecorded knowledge with them, causing a loss.
Promoting an experienced contributor to a core role removes them from the experienced contributor stock.
As contributors skill up, they graduate from being new to being experienced contributors.
New contributors joining the project increase the stock of new contributors.
As new contributors skill up, they transition out of the 'new' category, reducing its count.
When developers leave, the project loses their unique, unrecorded tacit knowledge.
As contributors internalize documented knowledge, it becomes part of the project's collective implicit knowledge.
The process of codifying implicit knowledge into documentation reduces its purely tacit form.
Negative interactions and burnout degrade the collaborative spirit and well-being of the community.
Positive interactions and reliable collaboration build trust and strengthen the community's health.
